subject: Re: [junit] Again... with testing interfaces...
msgSnippet: ... If you want to test whether X and Y each correctly respect the contract of I, then build an Abstract Test Case for I (TI) which you extend to TXAsI and
messageBody:
Thomas Robbs wrote:

> Imagine an interface I. Class X implements I. Class Y extends X.

If you want to test whether X and Y each correctly respect the contract
of I, then build an Abstract Test Case for I (TI) which you extend to
TXAsI and TYAsI, two separate suites that create an X and a Y,
respectively, and hand it to the tests in TI.

TI is abstract and defines all the tests for the methods in I plus
abstract creation methods.

TXAsI extends TI and implements the creation methods to return X
objects. TYAsI does the corresponding for Y.

If Y does not change any of the I-related behavior in X, then TYAsI
duplicates TXAsI. That's not necessarily a /bad/ thing, but it's worth
seeing.

If X or Y provide additional testable behavior beyond the contract of I,
then add separate test suites for each.

I don't like the nested class approach, and it seems to be vexing you,
so I vote to abandon it.
